One cultural practice that the Saxons adopted from the Norse and Danish cultures was the use of the longship, a type of ship with a shallow draft that allowed for quick navigation through shallow waters. The longship was used extensively by the Vikings for trade, exploration, and warfare.

The Saxons, who had close ties with the Norse and Danish cultures, also began to use the longship for their own purposes, especially for coastal defenses and raids. The adoption of the longship by the Saxons was significant, as it allowed them to expand their naval capabilities and to engage in naval warfare with greater effectiveness.

Additionally, the Saxons also adopted Norse and Danish motifs in their artwork and decorative designs. The intertwining of Anglo-Saxon, Norse, and Danish art styles is referred to as the "Animal Style" and can be seen in metalwork, jewelry, and manuscript illumination.

The Saxon adoption of these cultural practices from the Norse and Danish cultures demonstrates their openness and adaptability to outside influences. It also reflects the close relationships and alliances that existed between these neighboring societies.
